awd_titl_txt: Synthetic Biology Approaches to Elucidate and Exploit Nature's Selection of Lipid Modified RNA
awd_abstract_narration:
Natural RNA molecules are heavily decorated by various functional groups to diversify and fine-tune their structures and biological functions. Studying these RNA modifications has great significance in understanding fundamental RNA biology, studying evolution and developing new therapeutics. This project is focused on a recently discovered lipid modification on bacterial tRNAs. tRNA (also known as transfer RNA or soluble RNA) is the RNA molecule that carries amino acids to ribosome for protein synthesis in a cell, therefore is a very critical life molecule. The research will use synthetic biology approaches to address the fundamental question of why nature uses such a hydrophobic lipid group in hydrophilic RNA systems by elucidating the metabolic pathways of this lipid modification, as well as the structural and functional features of the working enzyme called SelU. In addition, based on this special pathway, the research will also develop novel molecular tools to detect, label and monitor specific tRNAs in cells. This project will provide educational and research training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, as well as local K12 teachers to use cutting-edge multidisciplinary approaches to solve fundamental biological problems and advance their scientific careers.

The systematic study of post-transcriptional chemical modifications of tRNAs have great significance in understanding RNA biology and its roles in evolution. Furthermore, many enzymes that mediate these processes have been demonstrated as targets for the development of new molecular tools or therapeutics. The main goal of this research is to explore tRNA geranylation, which is a recently discovered hydrophobic tRNA modification in several bacteria such as E. coli, E. aerogenes, P. aeruginosa and S. typhimurium. The geranylated 2-thiouridines are produced in the first anticodon position of tRNAs specific for lysine, glutamine, and glutamic acid by the enzyme SelU using geranyl pyrophosphate as the cofactor. It has been demonstrated that this hydrophobic terpene functional group affects the codon recognition patterns and reduces frameshifting errors during translation. Specifically, the geranyl group promotes wobble 2-thiouridine pairing with guanosine over adenosine and the long carbon chain of geranyl group is necessary to maintain this base pairing specificity in the context of RNA duplexes. This research will develop new chemical synthesis of RNA strands containing a series of geranyl-uridine analogues and identify the general rules for the in vitro codon specificity and ribosomal binding of these lipid modified tRNAs. In addition, this project will solve crystal structures of geranylated RNAs to elucidate their detailed structural features; and determine the structures of SelU-tRNA complexes for the mechanistic studies of this geranylation step. Furthermore, this research will develop novel molecular tools to detect, label and monitor specific tRNAs in cells.

por.por_cntn:
RNAs play critical roles in all the biological systems, exemplified by the currently ongoing COVID-19 pandemic that is resulted from the RNA coronavirus SARS-CoV-2. RNA molecules are often modified with different chemical groups by specific enzymes. These chemical modifications are necessary for RNAs to function normally and are closely related with many human diseases. In addition, these RNA modifications have been regarded as the chemical fossils left from the original stages of life. Therefore, studying these RNA modifications has great significance not only in understanding fundamental RNA biology and different disease mechanisms, but also in developing new therapeutics, as well as in studying evolution. This project is focused on a unique lipid modification, named geranyl group, in bacterial RNAs. The research uses synthetic biology approaches to address several fundamental questions such as what the biological functions of this geranyl group are; what the modification pathway of this geranylation process is; and why nature uses such a hydrophobic lipid group in bacterial RNA.

The tRNA geranylation has been found to play important biological roles in several bacteria such as E. coli, E. aerogenes, P. aeruginosa and S. Typhimurium. The geranylated 2-thiouridines are produced in the first anticodon position of tRNAs specific for lysine, glutamine, and glutamic acid by the enzyme SelU using geranyl pyrophosphate as the cofactor. It has been demonstrated that this hydrophobic terpene group affects the codon recognition patterns and reduces frameshifting errors during translation. As proposed in this project, during the past four years, we have chemically synthesized a series of geranylated RNA analogs and demonstrated that this geranyl group promotes the wobble U:G pair over the regular Watson-Crick U:A pair. We also found that this ten-carbon-long lipid chain has the unique length necessary to maintain this base pairing discrimination and specificity in the context of RNA duplexes, representing a potential evolutionary advantage of this modification. In addition, we developed a new biochemical method to study and compare the ribosomal binding properties of modified tRNAs, and a new computational strategy for simulating and modeling the detailed interactions of the modified RNA as well as the tRNA-ribosome complexes. Furthermore, we also expressed and purified the native and mutated versions of SelU enzyme and carried out the mechanistic investigation for this modification pathway in terms of the enzymatic activities under different conditions, the substrate specificity and binding dynamics, providing a knowledge foundation for further biochemical studies and biomedical development of potential antibiotics centered on this tRNA modification pathway. 

This project has created over 10 publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals and provided training opportunities for five Ph.D. students, three master students, four undergraduate students at SUNY Albany, as well as four local high school students who are interested in pursuing science majors as their future careers. The students received professional training in this multidisciplinary project. Specifically, they gained the experience and expertise in the areas of organic synthesis, biochemistry, chemical biology, and cell biology, particularly in nucleosides synthesis, nucleic acid solid-phase synthesis, HPLC and gel purification of DNA and RNA oligonucleotides, biophysical studies such as thermodenaturation and CD measurements, RNA-protein and RNA-ligand binding studies, as well as RNA crystallization & structure determination. These training will help their scientific career development. Students also had chances to present their works and research progress in local and national research symposiums and conferences to build their connections with the big scientific research communities.
